MaY 25, 1951
art
It wes a hopelessly corrupt and inept government which
spawned the
Chinese Communists.
The people of China yearned for sone decent Leadership, any
leadership other then whet they had.
They did not turn to Communism.
They
turned
from
the Kuoninteng.
The unplessent truth is th t the Communiats have brought
something new
to Chine.
It serves no useful purpose merely to condemn the Reds.
It is
better,
rather, to analyze their strength and look for some means of competing.
Most of those
who have lately returned from Connunist China admit that there exists
a new order of honesty.
Soldiers are well disciplined and they fight with a new
spirit.
The Communists have wrought some truly grest changes.
Traina run on time.
They do not wait for some arrogent official uno is deliberately late in order to
keep the train weiting and then strut down the platform so that all enn see the big
shot for whom the train and ell its pessengers have been inconvenienced.
Porters
refuse tips.
So
do dining car miters.
Generals and publie officials cun't be
bought.
This is no brief for Chinese or any other kind of Conuunism but if we are
to defeat them we must recognize their strength as well or even better than their
weakness and
do something about it. More of that later.
He have the opportunity
as will be shown.
The Chinese Communiats promised land reforms. The New York FORLD TELEGRAM
AND SUN of April 12th had this to say:
"Red Chine's
"land reform" has developed into a vicious
countryside wer in many areas,
with both landlords and
Red cadres sent out to divide up the fams.
In some
sections the army has had to be called out.
Chairmen Liu Shao-chi admits "agrarian reform is a
flerce struggle," but is going ahesd in East, South-
Central and Northwest China."
The above dispatch is interesting in the light of a report by Winston
Churchill in his fourth book, "The Hinge of Fate" in which he relates a conference
with Stalin as follows:
"Tell ne," I asked, "have the stresses of this war been as bad to you
personally as carrying through the polley of the Collective Farms?"
-... â€¢
"Oh, no," he said, "the Collective Fern policy was a terrible atruggle."
"I thought you would have found it bed," said I, "becuse you were not
deling with a few score thousends of aristocrats or big landowners, but with
millions of small men.*
"Ten millions," he said, holding up his hands.
"It was fearful.
Four
years it lasted.
It was absolutely necessary for fussia, if we were to avoid
periodie famines, to plough the land with tractors. He must mechanize our agri-
culture.
Then we gave tractors to the pessants they were sll spoiled in a few
mon tha.
Only Collective Farms with Workshops could handle tractors. We took
the grestest trouble to explain it to the pessents.
It was no use arguing with
then.
After you have said all you can to a persent he says he must go home and
consult his wife, and he must consult his herder.*
....*After he has talked it
over with them he always answers that he does not want the Collective Ferm and he
-
1 -

would rather do without the tractors."
*What happened?" I asked.
"Oh, well," he said, "many of then agreed to come in with us.
Some of
then were given land of their own to cultivate in the province of Tomsk or the
province of Irkutsk or farther north, but the great bulk were very unpopular und
were wiped out by their laborers."
*There was a considerable pease.
Then, "Not only have we vastly in-
creased the food supply, but we have improved the quality of the grain beyond &11
nessure.
A11 kinds of
grain used to be grown.
Now no one is allowed to sow any
but the standard Soviet grain from one and of our country to the other.
If they
do they
are severely desit with. This neans another large ineresse in the food
supply."
It is interesting to note how closely the Russian-treined Chinese Com-
munists are following the Moscow pettern.
Those who rule China today from Peking
may well apply the Russian program to the grent plain country of northern Chine
were agriculture is largely the production of grain and the same collective
ferns with nechanized euipment may be successfully operated.
However, the
economy of southern and western Chins is largely tied to the cultivation of rice.
Generally speaking,
the rice paddy is necessarily a amall tract of
ground which
does not lend itself to mechanised production.
Furthermore, the Chinese people,
who differ from other
peoples in so many respects, have one outstanding difference -
the people of the north are the lazy, indolent ones while the people of the south
have all the spirit and progressiveness. They are not docile as those of the
north.
If we are going to do something about China it should be done quickly.
The Chinese individusl known to the Old China Hand was on the averge a hardworking,
good-humored citizen who had been taught from erliest childhood
to respect and
revere his elders,
to preotice the virtuea me most admire, of humility, modesty,
tolerance.
The average
Chinese possessed these qualities
plus a fine sense of
responsibility, & willingness to work hard from dawn to dusk.
He thought of
himself first,
of his fanily second, of the little town that he came from third
and of the State
83
very
bed fourth.
Now the children are being taken away
from the parents and the old virtues are diving my to a systen of instruction
calculated to
produce a
churlish fellow who has none of the old virtues but rather
is taught
thit the State comes first, and thit he should forget his little tom,
his family and himself.
He is teught that China was a cultured netion when we
foreigners
were still
seveges.
If the Communist doctrines are taught to the younger
generation for fifteen years there will be no more China as we knew it but an
entirely different
race of people with
whom we or our children shell have to deal.
Therefore it is important that if Chine is to be returned to the company of free
nations we should
do something about it and soon.
The Chinese, particularly those of the south and west, have an intense
love of the good erth.
True, that is almost a biological urge but the Chinese
possess it
to a marked degree.
The Chinese peasant wenta to own s piece of land
which he
can improve and
pass on to his children.
He wants no part of a systen
of collectivized farms.
That is where our systen of private ownership of land hes
ite greatest
He will
go to almost any length to acquire
but nder
the old
system of Chiang Kai-shek and his corrupt regime the small landomers lived
2 -

perpetuslly on the brink of bankruptey brought and held thare by
taxes of every
enceivable type,
often paid years in advince and used not for
the development
of the countrycide, education or publie worka but rather to support corrupt gov-
ernment officials and their aries.
If we are to do anything about fomenting an
uprising in the south and weatern
China (and we should - soon) it will have to
be based upon the promise of land
reforms and honest administration.
We should
give our support only to those who are willing to dedicate themselves unequi-
vocally to that commitment.
The successful lesdership
of any
revolution in
southern or western Chins must be under sodeone other than Chiang Kei-shek.
The
Gene aliasino is honest but he has almys permitted his henchmen to
engege in
every type of corruption.
Those recently returned from Chine report that there
are fer if any Chinese even anong those who face the purge who would welcome
Chiang Kal-shek back to the meinland.
However,
80 far as Chiang 1a
concerned
he la in control of Formosa and must be dealt with.
While this would not have
been possible in the pest it would be possible today to put a man in Ching Kai-
shek's orgenization very
much as the benka put a work-out"
man into an organization
which is in finanoial difficulty.
Such a man should lave a military beckground
in order that he might understand all of the military implie tions, the possibilities
and the probabilities.
He should be a strong man with a
passion for anonynity
rether than publieity.
He should be willing to
"ait in
the beck room and direct
with a minimun of
publicity and ae speeches.
He would compel
Chiang Kai-shei to
eppoint lenders of integrity and ability to proceed to the mainland
for the or-
ganisation of many counter-revolutions in south and western China.
These men
must be given the
assurance and in some way guarented three besie principles in
order to secure support:
(2)
Lind reforms with the promise of ressonable taxes
for local improvementa,
anitation, aids to sgriculture; (2)
of land under these lend reforms,
and (3)
The introduetion
paDer currencT.
The experience of Chinese with paper noney has never been good
but since
the war the average Chinese is more than ever convinced that paper
money - no piper money - is any good.
He will avidly exchange a hatful of paper
money
for one
silver dollar.
Promises, 1f made by responsible lesders, backed by
armed forces with ailver dollars to buy rather than commandeer would unleash long
pent-up forces among the Chinese of south and western Chine, of such strength as
to overwhelm and
overthrow the Communiat Goverment in those aress.
These leaders
should be supported fron the fortreas of Fornoss by surface shipping and a well
organized airlift such as enabled Ten Hsi-shen to hold off the Communiats at Tel
Yun for months, when he ma entirely surrounded.
There are today
honest and sincere Chinese leaders in Hongkong and Formoss
could relly substantil aupport anong the people of western and southern China
but they are unwilling
to undertake such a program because they know that if they
were successful Chiang Kal-shek himself would depose then.
They must be given
satisfactory assurances that no such course will be follored.
In order te give sueh men the backing of the Formosa Government our
representetive "in the back room" should be fully supported by the Anerdeen Govera-
roment with the British end French that no help
whatsoever would be extended to Chiang Kai-shek except through our representative
and his staff so that Ching Kal-shek would know one and for all that he could
not play one goverment against the other and that he would continue to get
support and sid fron abroad, especially ailver, only and solely through the recon-
mendations of the American representative.

*General liedemeyer has denonstrated extraordinary capabilities an well
as a remarkable ability to keep out of the heudlines and avoid personal
publicity.
He has spent a greet deal of time in Chins and has the complete confidence and
respect of Chiang Kei-shek as well as other Chinese leaders. He would be an
ides man for the post above mentioned.
For miny years Ching Kal-shek with a large aray, air force and some naval
forces wes uneble to exterminate a determined but small force of Communists in
Kiongsi Province.
Eventually in 1935 the Communists were driven out of Kiangsi
more by economie blockades, the need of selt and other busie foodstuffs, than any
111 tary success.
In the reverse of that episode, it will be clear that any well-
Jed, well-equipped, deterined group of Chinese patriots with the assistance of
airborne supplies would be able to stand off any Red forces that could be thrown
against them.
Especially is this true because of the feet that the grent messes
of Chinese people would be sympathetie to such a rebellion and would lend every
possible aid to protect rather than expose the members of such an organization.
Furthermore, the American support of auch a group of groups would be well received
in Chine.
It will take the Communists many years of propaganda to offuet the
enormous
popularity of Americs and American institutions throughout Chine.
May 25, 1951
*(This wus written before General Redemeyer resigned from the Army.)
